sentences.sentence: The problem was how to get the Witch( 女巫 ) back to her own world, or at any rate out of ours, as soon as possible.
Whatever happened, she must not be allowed to go rampaging( 横冲直撞 ) about the house.
Mother must not see her. And, if possible, she must not be allowed to go rampaging( 横冲直撞 ) about London either.
Digory had not been in the drawing-room when she tried to “blast( 毁灭 )” Aunt Letty, but he had seen her “blast( 毁灭 )” the gates at Charn:
so he knew her terrible powers and did not know that she had lost any of them by coming into our world.
And he knew she meant to conquer( 征服 ) our world.
At the present moment, as far as he could see, she might be blasting( 毁灭 ) Buckingham Palace( 白金汉宫 ) or the Houses of Parliament( 议会大厦 ):
and it was almost certain that quite a number of policemen had by now been reduced to little heaps( 一堆堆 ) of dust.
And there didn’t seem to be anything he could do about that.
"But the rings seem to work like magnets( 磁铁 ),” thought Digory. “If I can only touch her and then slip( 戴上 ) on my yellow, we shall both go into the Wood between the Worlds.
I wonder will she go all faint( 虚弱的 ) again there?
Was that something the place does to her, or was it only the shock of being pulled out of her own world?
But I suppose I’ll have to risk that. And how am I to find the beast?
I don’t suppose Aunt Letty would let me go out, not unless I said where I was going.
And I haven’t got more than twopence( 两便士，钱币 ).
I’d need any amount of money for busses and trams if I went looking all over London.
Anyway, I haven’t the faintest idea( 毫无头绪 ) where to look. I wonder if Uncle Andrew is still with her.”
It seemed in the end that the only thing he could do was to wait and hope that Uncle Andrew and the Witch( 女巫 ) would come back.
If they did, he must rush out and get hold of the Witch( 女巫 ) and put on his yellow Ring before she had a chance to get into the house.
This meant that he must watch the front door like a cat watching a mouse’s hole; he dared not leave his post for a moment.
So he went into the dining-room( 餐厅 ) and “glued his face” as they say, to the window.
It was a bow-window( 弓形窗 ) from which you could see the steps up to the front door and see up and down the street,
so that no one could reach the front door without your knowing. “I wonder what Polly’s doing?” thought Digory.
He wondered about this a good deal as the first slow half-hour ticked on.
But you need not wonder, for I am going to tell you.
She had got home late for her dinner, with her shoes and stockings( 袜子 ) very wet.
And when they asked her where she had been and what on earth she had been doing, she said she had been out with Digory Kirke.
Under further questioning she said she had got her feet wet in a pool of water, and that the pool was in a wood.
Asked where the wood was, she said she didn’t know.
Asked if it was in one of the parks, she said truthfully enough that she supposed it might be a sort of park.
From all of this Polly’s mother got the idea that Polly had gone off, without telling anyone, to some part of London she didn’t know,
and gone into a strange park and amused( 消遣 ) herself jumping into puddles( 水洼 ).
As a result she was told that she had been very naughty( 淘气的 ) indeed and that she wouldn’t be allowed to play with “that Kirke boy” any more if anything of the sort ever happened again.
Then she was given dinner with all the nice parts left out and sent to bed for two solid( 整整的 ) hours. It was a thing that happened to one quite often in those days.
So while Digory was staring out of the dining-room( 餐厅 ) window,
Polly was lying in bed, and both were thinking how terribly slowly the time could go.
I think, myself, I would rather have been in Polly’s position.
She had only to wait for the end of her two hours:
but every few minutes Digory would hear a cab( 出租马车 ) or a baker’s van( 装载面包的货车 ) or a butcher’s( 肉铺 ) boy coming round the corner and think “Here she comes,” and then find it wasn’t.
And in between these false alarms( 虚惊 ), for what seemed hours and hours, the clock ticked on and one big fly—high up and far out of reach—buzzed( 发出嗡嗡声 ) against the window.
It was one of those houses that get very quiet and dull( 无聊的 ) in the afternoon and always seem to smell of mutton( 羊肉 ).
During his long watching and waiting one small thing happened which I shall have to mention because something important came of it later on.
A lady called with some grapes for Digory’s Mother;
and as the dining-room( 餐厅 ) door was open, Digory couldn’t help overhearing( 无意中听到 ) Aunt Letty and the lady as they talked in the hall.
“What lovely grapes!” came Aunt Letty’s voice. “I’m sure if anything could do her good these would.
But poor, dear little Mabel! I’m afraid it would need fruit from the land of youth to help her now.
Nothing in this world will do much.” Then they both lowered their voices and said a lot more that he could not hear.
If he had heard that bit about the land of youth a few days ago he would have thought Aunt Letty was just talking without meaning anything in particular,
the way grown-ups( 成年人 ) do, and it wouldn’t have interested him.
He almost thought so now.
But suddenly it flashed upon his mind that he now knew (even if Aunt Letty didn’t) that there really were other worlds and that he himself had been in one of them.
At that rate there might be a real Land of Youth somewhere.
There might be almost anything.
There might be fruit in some other world that would really cure his mother!
And oh, oh—Well, you know how it feels if you begin hoping for something that you want desperately badly;
you almost fight against the hope because it is too good to be true;
you’ve been disappointed so often before.
That was how Digory felt. But it was no good trying to throttle( 扼杀 ) this hope.
It might—really, really, it just might be true. So many odd( 奇怪的 ) things had happened already.
And he had the magic rings.
There must be worlds you could get to through every pool in the wood.
He could hunt through them all. And then—Mother well again.
Everything right again. He forgot all about watching for the Witch( 女巫 ).
His hand was already going into the pocket where he kept the yellow ring, when all at once he heard a sound of galloping( 飞奔 ).
“Hullo! What’s that?” thought Digory. “Fire-engine? I wonder what house is on fire. Great Scott, it’s coming here. Why, it’s Her.”
I needn’t tell you who he meant by Her.
First came the hansom( 双轮有蓬马车 ). There was no one in the driver’s seat.

On the roof—not sitting, but standing on the roof—swaying( 摇摆 ) with superb( 极好的 ) balance as it came at full speed round the corner with one wheel in the air—was Jadis the Queen of Queens and the Terror of Charn.
Her teeth were bared( 龇着的 ), her eyes shone like fire, and her long hair streamed out behind her like a comet( 彗星 )’s tail.
She was flogging( 鞭打 ) the horse without mercy( 仁慈 ).
Its nostrils( 鼻孔 ) were wide and red and its sides were spotted with foam( 白沫 ).
It galloped( 飞奔 ) madly up to the front door, missing the lamp-post( 灯柱 ) by an inch, and then reared( 用后腿直立 ) up on its hind legs( 后腿 ).
The hansom( 双轮有蓬马车 ) crashed into the lamp-post( 灯杆 ) and shattered( 使碎裂 ) into several pieces.
The Witch( 女巫 ), with a magnificent( 优美的 ) jump, had sprung clear just in time and landed on the horse’s back.
She settled herself astride( 跨坐地 ) and leaned forward( 前俯 ), whispering things in its ear.
They must have been things meant not to quiet it but to madden it.
It was on its hind legs( 后腿 ) again in a moment, and its neigh( 马的嘶鸣声 ) was like a scream; it was all hoofs( 蹄 ) and teeth and eyes and tossing( 甩动的 ) mane( 鬃毛 ).
Only a splendid rider could have stayed on its back.
Before Digory had recovered his breath a good many other things began to happen.
A second hansom( 双轮有蓬马车 ) dashed( 冲 ) up close behind the first: out of it there jumped a fat man in a frock-coat( 男礼服大衣 ) and a policeman.
Then came a third hansom( 双轮有蓬马车 ) with two more policemen in it.
After it, came about twenty people (mostly errand( 商店跑差 ) boys) on bicycles, all ringing their bells and letting out cheers and cat-calls( 嘘声 ).
Last of all came a crowd of people on foot: all very hot with running, but obviously enjoying themselves.
Windows shot up in all the houses of that street and a housemaid( 女佣 ) or a butler( 男管家 ) appeared at every front door. They wanted to see the fun.
Meanwhile an old gentleman had begun to struggle shakily out of the ruins of the first hansom( 双轮有蓬马车 ).
Several people rushed forward to help him;
but as one pulled him one way and another another, perhaps he would have got out quite as quickly on his own.
Digory guessed that the old gentleman must be Uncle Andrew but you couldn’t see his face; his tall hat had been bashed( 猛撞 ) down over it.
Digory rushed out and joined the crowd.

article_info.previous: 一度幻想女王会爱上自己Uncle Andrew, 回到卧室精心打扮了自己一番。由于没有钱，他就厚着脸皮找Aunt Letty借钱，但惨遭拒绝。就在这时，女巫打开了大门，把Aunt Letty重重地摔在了床垫上。此时毫不知情的Digory在想什么呢？

article_info.share_words: There might be almost anything. There might be fruit in some other world that would really cure his mother!

question.en: In this chapter, what was Digory thinking about?

options.cn: 如何把女巫带回她自己的世界。
options.en: How to get the Witch back to her own world.
How to get along with Uncle Andrew.

analysis: 文中提到“The problem was how to get the Witch back to her own world, or any rate of ours, as soon as possible.”由此得知Digroy现在想的问题是如何把女巫带回她的魔法世界，因此选A。

question.cn: 女王在现实世界的目的是什么？
question.en: What was the purpose of the Witch in the real world?

analysis: 文中提到“And he knew she meant to conquer our world.”由此可知，女巫在现实世界的目的是为了征服这个世界，因此选C。

question.cn: 当Polly的父母询问她去哪里了，她的回答是？
question.en: When Polly’s parents asked where she had gone, what was her answer?

options.en: She said she had read books in the library.
She said she had done homework at school.
She said she had been out with Digory.

analysis: 文中提到“when they asked her where she had been and what on earth she had been doing, she said she had been out with Digory Kirke.”由此可知，当Polly的父母询问她去了哪里，Polly说她和Digroy一起在外面玩耍，因此选C。

question.cn: 看望Digory妈妈的女士给她带去了什么水果？
question.en: What fruit did a lady bring to Digory’s mother?

analysis: 文中提到“A lady called with some grapes for Digory’s Mother.”由此可知女士带了一些葡萄来看Digory的妈妈，因此选C。

question.cn: 根据情节，Digory的母亲发生了什么事？
question.en: According to the plot, what happened to Digroy’s Mother?

analysis: 文中提到“There might be almost anything. There might be fruit in some other world that would really cure his mother.”由此可知Digory希望在魔法世界有神奇的水果可以治好他的妈妈，可知Digory的妈妈身患重病，因此选C。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第28天
